newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Food shortage tops agenda in U.N. visit to Kabul.
newsitem.headline: Food shortage tops agenda in U.N. visit to Kabul.

text.p: The U.N. special representative to Afghanistan visited Kabul on Thursday to discuss the country's food shortage and the purist Islamic Taleban's policy towards women.

Special representative Norbert Holl said he recently visited the southern Afghan city of Kandahar, where most of the Taleban leadership is based, and met acting Foreign Minister Mullah Mohammed Ghaus.
Holl said Ghaus had brought up the subject of the food shortage.

"He asked the United Nations to help overcome this food shortage, and I promised him to take action on that," said Holl, speaking at Kabul airport after a two and a half hour visit to the Afghan capital.
The price of wheat flour, one of the staples of the Afghan diet, has increased by more than 400 per cent since the beginning of the year.
Flour supplies to Afghanistan have been severely curtailed by a shortage in neighbouring Pakistan, the source of most of Afghanistan's supplies.
"One of the main problems is that they have difficulties to get the food supply through Pakistan. This is a political matter," Holl said.
"This is something that has already been discussed with the Pakistanis, which I will take up again and which will also be taken up in New York."
Holl said he also discussed the issue of women's education with various Taleban officials and was hopeful that in time the leadership would allow women back into education and employment.
The Taleban have closed girls' schools in the areas they control and have banned women from employment except in the medical sector.
"We have to keep telling the Taleban that gender is a big issue and I am sure that there is a certain flexibility in the overall behavior of the Taleban.
"When they tell me that in the future they will try to find some ways to accommodate girls and women in education, I am inclined to belive that. Let's give them some more time," he said.
Holl also said that despite his mission's lack of success in brokering peace in Afghanistan, he had not detected any frustration during a recent visit to the United Nations in New York.

"I know that I have not achieved a great deal of success, nevertheless there is no sense of frustration. I think that they are happy that I am here and that I am doing the job, and they all pledged full support."
